responses.content: Q3 revenue was a record $16 billion, up 22% YoY. Adjusted EBITDA was $10.7 billion, up 30% YoY. Semiconductor revenue was $9.2 billion, up 26% YoY, driven by AI semiconductor revenue of $5.2 billion (up 63% YoY). Current consolidated backlog hit a record $110 billion.

XPU business accelerated to 65% of AI revenue. We have secured over $10 billion of orders for AI accelerators from a fourth qualified customer, which will ship strongly in beginning of 2026. Demand from the existing 3 customers continues to grow. We expect the outlook for fiscal 2026 AI revenue to improve significantly.

AI networking demand remains strong. We launched Tomahawk 6 (102.4T Ethernet switch) which flattens networks to 2 tiers, and Jericho4 (51.2T Ethernet fabric router) for scaling across data centers beyond 200,000 compute nodes. We believe Ethernet is applicable to scale-up, scale-out, and scale-across challenges.
For Q4 2025, we forecast AI semiconductor revenue to be approximately $6.2 billion, up 66% YoY.

Non-AI semiconductor demand is slow to recover. Q3 revenue was $4 billion. Broadband showed strong sequential growth, but enterprise networking and server storage were down. In Q4, we forecast non-AI semiconductor revenue to grow low double digits sequentially to ~$4.6 billion driven by seasonality.

Infrastructure software revenue was $6.8 billion, up 17% YoY. Bookings were strong with TCV over $8.4B. We released VMWare Cloud Foundation (VCF) 9.0. Over 90% of our top 10,000 customers have bought VCF. We expect Q4 software revenue to be ~$6.7 billion, up 15% YoY.
The Board and I have agreed that I will continue as CEO of Broadcom through at least 2030.
Consolidated revenue $16.0B (+22% YoY). Gross margin 78.4%. Adjusted EBITDA $10.7B (67% margin). Free cash flow $7.0B (44% of revenue). Cash position $10.7B.
Q4 consolidated revenue ~$17.4B (+24% YoY). Semiconductor revenue ~$10.7B (+30% YoY), with AI revenue ~$6.2B (+66% YoY). Infrastructure software ~$6.7B (+15% YoY). Adjusted EBITDA ~67%.

analyst_questions.question: What changed to drive the significant improvement in 2026 AI outlook? Is it the 4th customer or existing demand?
How should we think about the magnitude of the cyclical upturn for non-AI segments from the bottom? Are you seeing order improvements?
Can you quantify the new fiscal '26 AI guidance (accelerating vs 60%)? How will the networking vs custom mix evolve?
Can you parse out the $110 billion backlog? How much is AI vs non-AI vs software?
How is the dialogue going with the other 3 prospects beyond the 4 customers? Is the 1 million unit goal for 2027 still intact?
How do you view the universe of additional prospects beyond the 7 identified? Are there others worthy of a custom chip?
Why is the Jericho4 and scale-across market developing materially now? Why is it important for inference?
Have you completely converted the top 10,000 accounts to VCF? Are you seeing cross-selling benefits?
Can you help understand the gross margin guide (down 70 bps) given the mix shift?
Can you categorize the 4th customer (hyperscale vs LLM maker)? What is the time frame for the $10 billion orders?
How does your scale-up Ethernet momentum compare to UALink/PCIe? How meaningful is the Tomahawk Ultra/scale-up opportunity?
Do you view competition increasing on the ASIC or networking side (UALink/PCIe)?
Why should we not think your XPU share at existing customers will become bigger than GPU share long term?
